page.title: 07LION SALT WORKS Est.1842.
page.content: The Works was founded 143 years ago in Marston by the Thompson family who still own the works today. Brine was pumped out of the ground by a beam pump known as a "nodding donkey". It was put into huge salt pans fired by coal. As the brine evaporated, salt crystals formed on the surface, increased in weight and size and fell to the bottom. Size and weight were controlled by varying the temperature of the brine. The salt was raked to the side of the pan and was shovelled into Peg Top tubs. It was compressed by a Mundler to obtain the required weight per tub. After the salt had been drained it was taken to the hot house for drying. The Thompson family still operate the firm today using traditional methods. They are now the only open pan block salt makers in the world and are a tourist attraction.
